description:
Anguilla anguilla, commonly known as the European eel or the common eel, is a species of eel that belongs to the family Anguillidae. This catadromous fish is native to the eastern Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, and the Baltic Sea.

The European eel is a long, snake-like fish with a cylindrical body and a distinct snout. Its skin is smooth and scaleless, and it has a distinctive lateral line that runs along its body. The color of the eel can vary from a dark greenish-brown on the back to a yellowish-white on the belly.

Anguilla anguilla is an important commercial and recreational species, and it has been the subject of extensive scientific research due to its unique life cycle. The species is known for its remarkable migratory behavior, as the adult eels undertake a long journey from their feeding grounds in Europe to their spawning grounds in the Sargasso Sea, located in the western Atlantic Ocean.

The European eel is considered a critically endangered species due to a combination of factors, including overfishing, habitat degradation, and the impact of climate change on its migratory patterns. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this ecologically and economically important species.
